chapter.title: Timekeeping Configuration
chapter.para: This chapter discusses all rules and configurations for Time keeping module of KPME. All rules and configurations can be accessed through maintenance documents listed under the Timekeeping section on the maintenance tab.

caption.para: Timekeeping section on the application's maintenance tab.

chapter.para: Please note that most of the configurations in Time keeping module rely heavily on configurations made in the HR and payroll module and therefore cannot be completed without setting those up properly.

section.title: Clock Location Rule
section.para: This feature enables administrators to restrict clock entry locations by defining approved IP addresses for Timekeeping use. Clock location rules can be set system wide, or as granular as a specific employee job record. In case of having more than one valid clock location rule for an assignment, the most specific rule for that assignment will be enforced by the system.

important.para: A clock location rule will not restrict the clock action from an unapproved IP but will add a note to the timesheet indicating that the clock action was from an "unapproved location".

section.para: Regardless of a rule, the IP address is captured on every clock action and can be seen on the Clock Log Inquiry page.
Table below shows fields used to record and maintain a clock location rule along with their description.

procedure.title: Setting up a clock location rule

step.para: Go to Clock Location Rule Document Page by clicking on the link in Timekeeping section on the maintenance tab.
To create a new rule, click on the create new button on top right of the lookup page.
On the Document Overview tab, Enter a short description of what you're going to do. For example: clock location rule for IU-UITS
You can also fill out the non-required fields for a brief explanation of the work you are doing or an organization document number for reference.
On the next tab, Clock Location Rule Maintenance, all fields are required, however you can skip specifying any field by entering the '%' character as wild card.
Enter a date by either selecting from the small calendar widget or manually writing it in the effective date text box.

Enter a department ID to set the clock location for it. You can use the lookup to select a department by clicking the magnifying glass or enter the ID manually in the input field. You can also use '%' to generalize this rule to all departments.
Enter a work area. You have the same options as in the previous step.
Enter a principal ID to enforce your rule on only one employee or use '%' to cover all employees that match your other criteria.
Enter a job number.
Set the rule Active by checking the box. You can create a rule and leave the box unchecked. The rule will be created but will not be active and therefore will not affect employees' clock actions.

On the IP address tab, you need to specify an approved IP address. You can use the '%' character wildcard in any of the IP address sections, starting from the rightmost section, to cover a progressively larger set of addresses.
You can add multiple addresses by adding them one by one.
At this step, you've filled in all the required fields, so you can route your document by clicking submit button at the bottom of the page.

Make sure that your document is successfully submitted by looking for a message on top of the page saying Document was successfully submitted.. In case of any errors, you will see red markers appearing next to the fields that are filled correctly.

section.para: Like any other documents in the system, submitting the document will place it in the workflow for further process. You can track the status of your document by looking it up through document search.

row.entry: The Effective date for which the IP address validation will be effective. This date needs to be on/prior to the date the rule to takes effect. When editing, it will determine the date the new values go into effect.

If a department is defined, only entries associated with a job in that department will be subject to IP address validation. Wild card of (%) is acceptable as input for this field. Validates against the department table.
If a work area is defined, only entries associated with a job in this work area will be subject to IP address validation. Wild card of (%) is acceptable input. Validates against the work area table.
If a principal ID is defined, only this specific employee will be subject to IP address validation. Wild card of (%) is acceptable as input for this field.
If a job number is defined, only this specific employees job will be subject to IP address validation. Wild card of (%) is acceptable as input.

The IP Address to be used for validation. A wild card can be placed at the end of a partial IP address to represent a range of IP addresses. To grant exceptions to rules in effect, wild card the IP address field.
Status of the IP validation rule, checked indicates Active, unchecked indicates Inactive.

tip.para: To eliminate a clock location rule, insert a new effective dated row for that rule and uncheck the active box on the rule to be eliminated.

section.title: Daily Overtime Rule
section.para: The Daily Overtime Rule is used to define the parameters by which daily overtime is calculated. This calculation runs prior to the weekly overtime calculation and can be limited to specific populations by pay type, location, dept, and work area. All of these parameters can be replaced by a wild card value (%) allowing the user to designate a rule at different levels.

procedure.title: Setting up a Daily Overtime Rule

step.para: Put in a short description of the daily overtime rule you are creating.
Pick a date that you want your new rule to be effective from.
Select a Location for your rule. If a location is defined, only jobs in that exact location will be subject to daily overtime rule.
Select a pay type. If a pay type is defined, only entries associated with a job of this pay type will be subject to the defined overtime rule.
Select a Department. If a department is defined, only entries associated with a job in this department will be subject to the this rule.
Select a work area. If a work area is defined, only entries associated with a job that has this work area will be subject to this rule.
Enter a maximum gap of time in minutes that is allowed before daily overtime is considered invalid. This field is explained in more detail later in this document.
Enter the number of hours which, if exceeded, result in daily overtime.
Check the box if you want your rule to be active. Unchecked means that the rule is not active. You can still create the rule, even if you leave it as inactive.

In "Convert to Earn Code" you specify the earn code which hours will be converted to as overtime.
Only earn codes that are designated as an Overtime Earn Code can be used
In "Convert from Earn Group", select an earn group which contains the list of earn codes that are summed to the daily max hours to be converted to overtime.
Route your rule document by clicking submit button at the bottom of the page.

section.para: The table below lists all fields on the Daily Overtime Rule Document along with their descriptions.

row.entry: Effective date for which the daily overtime rule will be effective. This date needs to be on/prior to the date the rule to takes effect. When editing, it will determine the date the new values go into effect.
If a location is defined, only entries associated with a job in this location will be subject to the defined rule. Validates against the location table.
If a department is defined, only entries associated with a job in this department will be subject to the defined rule. Validates against the department table.
If a work area is defined, only entries associated with a job that has this work area will be subject. Validates against the work area table.

Used to identify a maximum gap of time in minutes that is allowed before daily overtime is considered invalid. For example, a rule that states daily overtime is given for working over 8 hours with a max gap of 30 minutes implies that employee must work a total of 8 hours in the day and have a gap of no more than 30 minutes in the reporting of those hours to be eligible.
The number of hours which, if exceeded, result in daily overtime.
The earn code which hours will be converted to as overtime. Only earn codes that are designated as an Overtime Earn Code can be used (see Earn Code Maintenance Document).
The earn group defined (using the Earn Group maintenance doc) which contains the list of earn codes that are summed to the daily max hours to be converted to overtime.
Status of the rule, checked indicates Active, unchecked indicates Inactive. If the rule is being eliminated, insert a new effective dated row and uncheck the active box on the existing row.

section.title: Weekly Overtime Rule
section.para: The Weekly Overtime Rule defines the steps necessary to calculate weekly overtime. This maintenance document page allows the user to establish which earn codes count towards the calculation of overtime hours, what overtime earn code to use and where the overtime hours should be applied. This maintenance document is different because there is only one Weekly Overtime rule in effect at a time.

note.para: There is no create new link, the link directs straight to the page to add steps to or edit the existing steps.

procedure.title: Setting up a weekly overtime rule

step.para: Put in a short description of the weekly overtime rule you are creating.
Pick a date that you want your new rule to be effective from.
Enter the earn group you have defined to use for this rule using earn group maintenance document. You can use the lookup widget to find the right earn group.
In "Convert from Earn Group", select an earn group which contains the list of earn codes to be converted to overtime.

In "Convert to Earn Code" specify the earn code which hours will be converted to as overtime.
Only earn codes that are designated as an Overtime Earn Code can be used
Enter the step number. You can have multiple steps for a weekly overtime rule and use different earn codes for each step.
Enter the maximum number of hours you want to allow for overtime calculation in each FLSA period.
Check the box if you want your rule to be active. Unchecked means that the rule is not active. You can still create the rule, even if you leave it as inactive.
Route your rule document by clicking submit button at the bottom of the page.

important.para: If there is only one step in weekly overtime calculation, the Convert from Earn Group will be the same as Max Hour Earn Group. If there are multiple steps in overtime calculation, the 'convert from earn group' will be an earn group which is a subset of the 'max hours earn group'.

caption.para: An overtime block is created on this timesheet on Friday. The Maximum hours was set to 40 so any extra hours after 40 are converted to Overtime.

row.entry: Effective date for which the Weekly Overtime Rule will be effective. This date needs to be on or prior to the date the rule is to take effect. When editing, it will determine the date the new values go into effect.
The earn group defined (using the Earn Group maintenance document) to represent the codes which count towards the calculation of overtime.
The earn group defined to represent the earn codes to be converted to overtime.

The default earn code which other earnings will be converted to (ex: OVT). Only earn codes that are designated as an Overtime Earn Code can be used (see Earn Code Maintenance Document). This earn code is used for overtime hours unless the Work Area for the Assignment has a designated Default Overtime Earn Code (see Work Area Maintenance Document).
This enables the definition of multiple steps in the hours conversion for overtime.
Define the maximum hours in an FLSA period for overtime calculation (For example: 40)

section.title: Department Lunch Deduction Rule
section.para: The Department Lunch Deduction rule is used to define automatic lunch deductions. This rule only applies to clock entry employees and rules can be set system wide, or as granular as a specific employee job record. The most specific rule for a given assignment will be enforced. Employees subject to the automatic lunch time deduction will not see the lunch in/out buttons (even if that system setting is enabled).

caption.para: Department Lunch Deduction Rule Maintenance document

procedure.title: Setting up a department lunch deduction rule

step.para: Put in a short description of the lunch reduction rule you are creating.
Pick a date that you want your new rule to be effective from.
Select a Department. If a department is defined, only entries associated with a job in this department will be subject to the this rule.
Select a work area. If a work area is defined, only entries associated with a job in this work area will be subject to this rule.

If you want to apply this rule to only one user, enter their principal ID in the form. You can use the lookup widget to do this. To leave this field as general as possible, simply enter a wildcard character (%) as principal ID. That means all users that match your other criteria.

If you are creating this rule for one specific employee, you can define a job number to only apply the rule to one specific job. If a principal id is not specified simply use a wildcard character (%).
Next, enter the number of minutes you want the system to deduct as lunch time. (For example: 30)
Enter the number of hours that the system should consider as a work shift to apply this lunch deduction rule. (For example: 6)
Check the box if you want your rule to be active. Unchecked means that the rule is not active. You can still create the rule, even if you leave it as inactive.
Submit the document after filling out all required fields.

caption.para: This is how a lunch deduction appears on an employee's timesheet

table.title: Department Lunch Deduction Rule Document fields

row.entry: The Effective date for which the automatic lunch deduction rule will be effective. This date needs to be on/prior to the date the rule is to take effect. When editing, it will determine the date the new values go into effect.
If a department is defined, only entries associated with a job in this department will be subject to the automatic lunch deduction. Wild card of (%) is acceptable as input.
If a work area is defined, only entries associated with a job in this work area will be subject to the automatic lunch deduction. Wild card of (%) is acceptable as input.
If a principal ID is defined, only this specific employee will be subject to the automatic lunch deduction. Wild card of (%) is acceptable as input.
If job number is defined, only this specific employees job will be subject to the automatic lunch deduction. Wild card of (%) is acceptable as input.
The amount of minutes to be deducted as a lunch.
The number of hours which must be met in order for the deduction to occur.
Status of the automatic lunch deduction rule, checked indicates Active, unchecked indicates Inactive.
User which set up the lunch rule.

tip.para: To eliminate an existing rule, insert a new effective dated row and uncheck the active box on the existing rule.

note.para: To show departmental lunch deductions on the timesheet, add a new Earn Code LUN with a Record Method of Hours.

section.title: Grace Period Rule
section.para: The Grace Period Rule is an optional rule that results in the system rounding clock in/outs times based on the chosen factor. This rule rounds up and down based on the clock action time. The benefit of having a grace period rule is that it eliminates small fractions of time and makes calculations less complicated for those employees trying to reach standard hours for the week. It also alleviates the rush to clock in or out right on the hour.

procedure.title: Setting up a grace period rule

step.para: Put in a short description of the grace period you are creating.
Pick a date that you want your new grace period to be effective from.
Enter the minutes that will define the grace period. As you can see in the table below, the minute entered will become the fourth value in a range of six minutes that comprise the grace period.
Check the box if you want your grace period to be active. Unchecked means that the rule is not active. You can still create the rule, even if you leave it as inactive.
Submit the document after filling out all required fields.

section.title: Shift Differential Rule
section.para: The Shift Differential Rule defines rules for assigning shift differentials. This rule applies shift automatically to earn codes when clock times are specified. If an earn code is entered with an hours amount (ex: Sick), the rule would not assign shift. Rules can be set system wide, or on specific populations (most specific rule for that assignment will be enforced). The rule will add a specified earn code to the eligible shift hours. Different earn codes are needed to result in different shift amounts (e.g. each earn code attached to a shift rule has its own associated rate for payment in Payroll). The shift differential rule only assigns the additional earnings codes to shift hours within the specified shift time period. Any hours outside of the shift period will not be assigned shift.

procedure.title: setting up a shift differential rule

step.para: Put in a short description of the shift differential rule you are creating.
Pick a date that you want your rule to be effective from.

Enter a Location for your rule. If a location is defined, only jobs in that exact location will be subject to shift differential rule. You can also use a wildcard character (%) to cover all locations.
Enter a salary group to limit this rule only to this salary group. You can also use a wildcard character (%) to cover all salary groups.
Enter a valid pay grade. If it is defined, only jobs with this pay grade will be subject to this rule. You can also use a wildcard character (%) to cover all pay grades.
Enter the earn code to be applied to an eligible shift.
Enter the earn code group that represents earn codes that will be converted to Shift Differential Earn Code.
Enter the begin time for an eligible shift.
Enter the end time for an eligible shift.
Enter the minimum number of hours a shift should be in order to qualify for shift differential.
Check the week days that are eligible for shift differential.
Enter the maximum number of minutes which can separate time blocks and still qualify as an eligible shift.
Check the box if you want your rule to be active. Unchecked means that the rule is not active. You can still create the rule, even if you leave it as inactive.
Enter the Pay Calendar Group record that defines the FLSA period.
Submit the document after filling out all required fields.

caption.para: An example of a shift differential time block can be seen on this Timesheet.

row.entry: The effective date which the shift differential rule will be effective. This date needs to be on or prior to the date the rule is to take effect.
If a location is defined, only entries associated with a job in this location will be subject to the shift rule. Wild card of (%) is acceptable as input.
If a salary group is defined, only entries associated with a job in this salary group will be subject to the shift rule. Wild card of (%) is acceptable as input.
If a pay grade is defined, only entries associated with a job in this pay grade will be subject to the shift rule. Wild card of (%) is an acceptable input.
The earn code that will be applied to the eligible shift.
The earn group defined to represent the earn codes to be converted to Shift Differential Earn Code.
The beginning time of the eligible shift.
The end time of the eligible shift. This could be on the following day if the eligible shift is overnight.
The minimum number of hours a shift must be in order to qualify for shift differential. A zero in this field would mean that there is no minimum shift requirement.
Check which days are eligible for shift differential.
The maximum number of minutes which can separate time blocks and still qualify as an eligible shift.
User that set up the shift rule.
Status of the shift differential rule, checked indicates Active, unchecked indicates Inactive.
Pay Calendar record that defines the FLSA period.

section.title: System Lunch Rule
section.para: System lunch rule is a system level setting which determines if the “Take Lunch” and “Return from Lunch” buttons display for clock entry employees. If the employee is subject to a lunch deduction rule, no lunch buttons will be displayed.

table.title: Fields on System Lunch Rule Document

row.entry: Effective date for which the system lunch rule will be effective. This date needs to be on or prior to the date of the rule to take effect.
When checked, Lunch buttons will be presented
Status of the rule, checked indicates Active, unchecked indicates Inactive.

tip.para: To eliminate a system lunch rule, insert a new effective dated row and uncheck the active check box on the existing row.

section.title: Time Collection Rule
section.para: The Time Collection Rule maintenance page is used to define how employees record time, via clock entry or manual entry. This rule can be defined at various levels including at a system level. The timesheet shows the clock tab for entry if the most specific rule for that assignment is marked as a clock user.

row.entry: The Effective date for which the time collection rule will be effective. This date needs to be on or prior to the date of the rule to take effect.
Department the time collection rule is associated with. A wild card (%) can be provided indicating the rule is in effect for all departments.
Work area the time collection rule is associated with. A wild card (%) can be provided indicating the rule is in effect for all work areas.
If this box is checked, clock entry will be required for recording time based on the department and work area values provided above.
Auto populated by the Principal ID of user who created the rule.
Status of the Time Collection Rule, checked indicates Active, unchecked indicates Inactive.
